descriptionSet.description: The image shows two buildings with a couple of trees in front of it and an attendant standing in front of the first house.

inscription.text: 410. "Barnes Court" the Residence of H. H. the Lient Governor. Simla.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: 410. "Barnes Court" the Residence of H. H. the Lient Governor. Simla.
description-en: The image shows two buildings with a couple of trees in front of it and an attendant standing in front of the first house. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: When the colonial state set about recreating a "home" in the hills, it did so in the image of the idealized rural English aristocracy. This brought with it a fairly rigid hierarchy. In the hill stations, social rank was closely matched with elevation. Hence Simla, the seat of the Viceroy, was at a higher elevation than the cantonment stations of Dagshai or Kasauli. The reason given for such distinctions in elevation and segregation was medical. Diseases were seen to accompany migrant Indian workers, hence the need to segregate them. And since the natives were deemed to have a natural tendency to huddle together, the native sections were left unsanitary and overcrowded, thereby jeopardizing the healthful purpose for the hill stations. Unsanitary conditions led to public health hazards, since disease does not respect racial lines and there were many epidemics in the hill stations. It can be concluded that the medical reasons for segregation were in actuality much less important than ideological ones. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The coloured attendant standing in front of the house can be seen as the only evidence for a non-european surrounding. (gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)

related literature: Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html (19.12.2010)(gs)
